Justification: Ichabod is introduced already as an outsider, and he remains so.
He courts Katrina, signaling potential social advancement.
Ichabod begins to believe in the Headless Horseman legend.
The confrontation with the Horseman forces a psychological shift into fear and desperation.
Ichabod disappears—whether real or symbolic, he is removed from the town’s story.
The town’s perception of Ichabod changes post-disappearance, cementing myth over man.
